senses.scientific: Richardson’s/Wyoming Ground Squirrel (Spermophilus spp), Uinta Ground Squirrel (Spermophilus armatus), Spotted Ground SquirrelSpermophilus spilosoma; Rock Squirrel: Spermophilus variegatus

senses.definition: extended to other similar small rodents

16.cultural: When the moon enticed the human woman up to the Heavens in mythological times, he did so by taking the form of a porcupine. This is the widely known story of “The Porcupine and the Woman who Climbed to the Sky.”

17.cultural: When the moon enticed the human woman up to the Heavens in mythological times, he did so by taking the form of a porcupine. This is the widely known story of “The Porcupine and the Woman who Climbed to the Sky.”

18.cultural: Porcupine quills were the most important and sacred item used for decorating clothes, blankets, tepee decorations, and similar items, especially before the arrival of trade beads. Porcupine quills were kept in special pouches made of animal stomachs and intestines.

19.cultural: The coyote is very important in Arapaho life and legend, but he is not a classic trickster figure, unlike the case for many other tribes such as the Navajo. Rather, he is often a helper-figure who comes to the rescue of humans. The coyote also occurs in many Nih’oo3oo (trickster) stories, where he is often a rival to the trickster, succeeding in tricking him in turn. In these stories, he approaches the role of a trickster figure himself, except that coyote rarely acts in gratuitous, inappropriate  and excessive ways like classic tricksters - he is simply wise and clever.

senses.scientific: Richardson’s/Wyoming Ground Squirrel: Spermophilus spp; Uinta Ground Squirrel: Spermophilus armatus; Spotted Ground Squirrel: Spermophilus spilosoma; Rock Squirrel: Spermophilus variegatus

senses.definition: extended to other similar small rodents

20.cultural: The wolf plays a much less important role in Arapaho culture and mythology than the coyote.

senses.note: The second term occurs in the story “Nih’oo3oo and the Seven Sisters,” and is an archaic form, perhaps meaning more specifically ‘black wolf.’ Kroeber gives it variously as wonitees and wooni’itees.

23.cultural: Swift Foxes were associated with the Kit (Swift) Fox Lodge age-grade ceremony (nouuhoowu’, nouuhnenno’). The skins were also used in the Spear Lodge (biitohoowu’) ceremony (The Arapaho, p. 170).
23.literal: little one who comes outside (from holes)

24.cultural: Arapaho mythology does not indicate a close sense of connection between the Arapaho and bears. When bears do appear, they seem to have typically been either somewhat dull-witted (as in a story where the trickster Nih’oo3oo kills the bears’ cubs and feeds them to the bears in a stew, then leads the adults  on a wild chase that results in him burning off their tails), or vaguely malevolent (as in the widely known story of the bear who chased a girl and her six brothers, clawing his way up what is known today as Devil’s Tower (wox niiinon = ‘bear’s tepee’ in Arapaho), and leading the children to transform into the seven stars known as the Pleiades (beenoku3i’ = ‘they sit clustered together’ in Arapaho).

senses.scientific: Black Bear: Ursus americanus; Grizzly: Ursus arctos

29.cultural: Raccoons were formerly kept as pets sometimes. When women were having difficulty nursing, they would be given young raccoons to suckle.

senses.note: In Salzmann’s field notes, his informant gives the term honi’ for ‘prairie dog, the littler one.’ The Wyoming Ground Squirrel lives in loose colonies, digs fairly conspicuous burrows, and often stands upright (sometimes called ‘picketpin’ colloquially), so it does resemble a small prairie dog in many ways, and it seems to be the prototypical honi’ for the Northern Arapaho.
senses.scientific: Richardson’s/Wyoming Ground Squirrel: Spermophilus spp; Uinta Ground Squirrel: Spermophilus armatus; Spotted Ground Squirrel: Spermophilus spilosoma; Rock Squirrel: Spermophilus variegatus

senses.note: Hayden’s report from 1863 uses no’ou(h) for ‘chipmunk.’ He does not give a word for ‘squirrel.’ It is likely that the older word cited in Schoolcraft was used specifically for tree squirrels, while the word no’ou(h) was used for chipmunks. In more recent times, as distinctions between  chipmunks and spotted/striped ground squirrels have been lost (so that xoxooyoni’ has become the general word), and as distinctions between types of small rodents more generally have received less attention, the word no’ou(h) has been shifted to mean tree squirrel specifically, but any unmarked squirrel-like rodent in general for many speakers.

senses.definition: extended to other similar small rodents

30.cultural: Raccoons were formerly kept as pets sometimes. When women were having difficulty nursing, they would be given young raccoons to suckle.

31.cultural: Raccoons were formerly kept as pets sometimes. When women were having difficulty nursing, they would be given young raccoons to suckle.

32.cultural: The skin of weasels was commonly used decoratively and on ceremonial/sacred items. Weasels were admired for their quickness and ferocity, and the use of the skins was thought to confer this power on the wearer.

senses.scientific: Ermine: Mustela erminea; Long-tailed weasel: Mustela frenata

38.cultural: Skunks are linked to traditional medicinal practice. The treatment for getting sprayed by a skunk, especially in the face and eyes, was to get a pair of  stinky, old moccasins and look into them with the eyes wide open. The odor was said to cleanse the eyes.

senses.scientific: Western spotted skunk: Spilogale gracilis; Striped skunk: Mephitis mephitis
senses.usage: xóúhu' is the older form of this word

39.cultural: Skunks are linked to traditional medicinal practice. The treatment for getting sprayed by a skunk, especially in the face and eyes, was to get a pair of stinky, old moccasins and look into them with the eyes wide open. The odor was said to cleanse the eyes.

senses.scientific: Western spotted skunk: Spilogale gracilis; Striped skunk: Mephitis mephitis
senses.usage: xóúhu' is the older form of this word

4.cultural: Arapahos believed that one should avoid camping around gopher holes, as this would cause sickness. Likewise, touching gophers was believed to cause sores. The propensity of gophers to carry disease-bearing fleas makes this idea quite reasonable.
4.literal: one who blows [dirt] out [of the ground]

41.cultural:
The otter was considered an especially powerful animal because it had power over both the land and the water. Its skin, when used in ceremonies, could represent the entire Earth because of this dual habitat (The Arapaho, p. 176). The skin was widely used in both tribal and personal sacred and ritual items.
Otter-skin was especially favored for making wraps for braids. The softness of otter skin was believed to symbolically “soften” or prevent injury from attacks (The Arapaho p. 176).

42.cultural: Mountain lion skins were especially favored for making quivers.

43.cultural: Bobcat fur was used occasionally in ceremonial objects and medicine bundles, but the animal played a minor role for the Arapaho.

44.cultural: Bobcat fur was used occasionally in ceremonial objects and medicine bundles, but the animal played a minor role for the Arapaho.

46.cultural: Elk were a major food source, second only to the buffalo. Elk meat was treated in the same ways as that of the Buffalo - jerked, dried, pounded and so forth. Elk spinal vertebrae were used to make carved jewelry, according to Nelson White.

47.cultural: Elk were a major food source, second only to the buffalo. Elk meat was treated in the same ways as that of the Buffalo - jerked, dried, pounded and so forth. Elk spinal vertebrae were used to make carved jewelry, according to Nelson White.

48.cultural: In Arapaho mythology and legend, the deer is associated with women and romantic desire. Deer were hunted using calls made of bone or wood, similar to whistles (The Arapaho, p. 22).

senses.note: Like several other words for animals (‘goose,’ ‘duck,’ ‘fish’) the former plural word for moose has become the singular and well as plural form in modern Arapaho.
Like several other words for animals (‘goose,’ ‘duck,’ ‘fish’) the former plural word for moose has become the singular and well as plural form in modern Arapaho.

54.cultural: Like other animals, the antelope was admired for certain specific qualities, and amulets or charms were made from parts of the animal in an effort to obtain the same qualities for the wearer. Kroeber (The  Arapaho, p. 441) describes an amulet made of antelope horn, and worn by a child. This was intended to make the child grow up and learn to walk quickly (like young antelopes, which must be able to get up and outrun predators as soon as possible). Such amulets were used to make horses run faster as well.

6.cultural: Arapahos note that the Shoshones are especially fond of prairie dogs as food. This is an important ethnographic stereotype held by the Arapahos. An older source (Michelson mss 3344) says that when prairie dogs were seen running from their towns, this was taken as the sign of a coming flood, especially in the spring.

senses.scientific: Black-tailed prairie dogs: Cynomys ludovicianus; White-tailed prairie dogs: Cynomys leucurus

senses.definition: diaper powder made from dried buffalo chips

75.cultural: This was a mythological buffalo, the first of its kind.

senses.definition: oldest buffalo, father of the buffalo
choice meat on the back of a buffalo, 'back fat'*
